conclusion: Both chambers have initial pressure p, volume V, and temperature T. The height of the cylinder is 2H. The initial volume of each chamber is V.

premise: The diaphragm is in equilibrium when the force due to pressure in the lower chamber equals the force due to pressure in the upper chamber plus the weight of the diaphragm.
conclusion: p_1 = p_2 + \frac{mg}{A} where A is the area of the diaphragm.

premise: When the diaphragm starts to leak, the pressure in the lower chamber increases slightly due to compression.
conclusion: The change in pressure can be expressed as \Delta p = \frac{mg}{A}.
Use the ideal gas law: PV = nRT. For adiabatic processes, PV^\gamma = \text{constant} where \gamma is the adiabatic index. For helium, \gamma = \frac{5}{3}.

premise: The new volume V_0 relates to the new pressure p + \Delta p.
Rearrange to find V_0: p \cdot V^{5/3} = (p + \Delta p) \cdot V_0^{5/3}.
Recall \Delta p = \frac{mg}{A} = \frac{mg}{V/H} = \frac{mgH}{V}. Substitute x to get \Delta p = px.
The volume V_0 of the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak is V_0 = V \left( \frac{1}{1 + x} \right)^{3/5}.
